social_posts.post_text:
Remember that upcycled J. Crew blouse made from Liberty of London fabric that I deconstructed? 👉🏻Swipe if you need a reminder!
.
So many of y'all were asking what I was going to make with it. 🤗
.
WELL, here it is! 🙌🏻 I turned it into this adorable quilted oven glove! 🧤 
.
I used @the.weekendquilter’s Star Bright Oven Glove pattern to make it and it's so stinkin' cute! 😍
.
👉🏻Swipe to see it up close and the cheery yellow fabric I used on the reverse side! 💛 I'm finishing up a second one so I'll have a set of two to use around the kitchen.
.
Have you ever made DIY oven gloves?
.

Flannel is the perfect fabric for the underside of a coaster - it’s nice and soft so it’ll keep your table top clean and scratch-free. 🥰 That’s why my quilted coaster kits include upcycled flannel 👉🏻 sourced from a blue men’s flannel button-down shirt (for the blue kits 💙) and an off-white bedsheet (for the pink kits 💗). Don’t worry - while the fabric was purchased second hand, both items were new and unused. 🧼 
.
‼️Coaster kits are still available via the link in my bio! ⏰ The live tutorial is happening on Saturday, March 18th at 10am PT on the Whatnot app so be sure to check it out and join in on the fun! 🧵 
.
Here’s a look at how I deconstructed this men’s flannel shirt for the fabric I needed for my coasters! ✂️ Given their consutrction, I find that using fabric scissors to cut out the seams (rather than pick them out with a seam ripper) works best for button downs. 
.
Do you ever repurpose button-down shirts for fabric? Let me know in the comments below! 👇🏻
.

Did you know that March is National Crafting Month? 🎉What are you making to celebrate? 
.
I’m mixing spring cleaning with quilting and partnering with @fiskars to turn old button-down shirts into a cute garden apron! #ad ♻️
.
When deconstructing button-down shirts for fabric, I find it easiest to use quality, sharp edge fabric scissors (👉🏻like these iconic Fiskars Orange-handled Scissors!) to cut along all of the seams - discarding cuffs, collars and any pieces with buttons along the way. ✂️
.
Once you have all of your fabric scraps in hand, use a rotary cutter to square them up and trim them to the size needed for your project. This Fiskars Easy Change DuoLoop Rotary Cutter works particularly well because of it’s 2-in-1 design allowing you to alternative between a 45mm and 60mm blade – making it perfect for any quilting project big or small! 🙌🏻
.
🔗 Links to the Fiskars tools I’m using are in my bio! Get a 20% discount when you use my code NEXTGENQUILTING20 at checkout!
.

Happy National Crafting Month! 💜
.
I’m celebrating in partnership with @fiskars ✂️ and turning these old button-down shirts into a cute quilted garden apron (a half apron with lots of functional pockets). ♻️ #ad
.
In the spirit of spring cleaning, I’ve been working to clean out a few closets around here. 👕 And in the process, I snagged these three button-down shirts from my husband’s donation pile to use in my project. 🙌🏻
.
I used Fiskars high quality, sharp edge fabric scissors (you know, the ones with the iconic orange handle? 🧡) to deconstruct them and then used the Fiskars Easy Change DuoLoop Rotary Cutter to square up all of my fabric scraps and trim them to size for my apron. Did you know you can alternate from a 45mm to a 60mm blade with this single cutter? 🤯 So cool! 
.
I’m pairing the upcycled shirt fabric with some cheery purples 💜 and greens 💚 to make two eight-point star quilt blocks that will go on the apron pockets. ⭐️ 
.
Can’t wait to show you the finished product! 🤗
.
In the meantime, links to the Fiskars tools I'm using are in my bio! ☝🏻 Get a 20% discount when you use my code NEXTGENQUILTING20 at checkout!
.

Raise your hand if binding quilts gives you heartburn. 🙋🏼‍♀️ The struggle to get the perfect corners and join those two loose tails at the end evenly is REAL. 🙈
.
Enter: The Quilt Binding Ruler by @vintagestitch_by_jenae 
.
Jenae is the queen of binding 👉🏻 she machine binds all the quilts I send her and they always look like PERFECTION. 🤌🏻 Good news is, she designed a ruler to help anyone (both domestic and long arm quilters) achieve the perfect quilting binding too! 🙌🏻
.
❗️Check out the blog post in my bio to learn more about how to use Jenae’s new ruler and where to get one!
.

I’ve always struggled with getting the perfect corners when binding my quilts (👉🏻swipe to see my countless failed attempts! 🙈). 
.
I never know when to stop sewing before I turn the corner and when I finally get around to the end, it takes me at LEAST 3 attempts when joining the tails to finally get it right. 🤦🏼‍♀️ Anyone else?
.
Which is why I’m excited to talk about the Quilt Binding Ruler by @vintagestitch_by_jenae – have you seen this thing?! #sponsored 
.
I’ve called on Jenae to longarm a couple of my quilts. It all started in a search for my first long arm quilter 👉🏻 I had NO IDEA what I was getting into. I wanted to send my quilt to someone local-ish in Northern California and I had a MILLION questions. I stumbled upon Jenae of Vintage Stitch via Instagram, sent her a DM and the rest is history. 💜
.
One of the things I ALWAYS ask her to do for me is attach my quilt binding. I HATE doing it myself. 😳 It never turns out right when I do it and she always does such a PERFECT job machine binding with her long arm machine. 🙌🏻
.
But guess what? She turned her binding expertise into a ruler to help us all bind better. 👏🏻 And then she asked me to try it out and show y’all how to use it with some visuals and graphics. 
.
So we partnered together on a blog post that demonstrates how to use her ruler to 1️⃣ connect binding strips with a diagonal seam, 2️⃣ get the perfect corners every time, and 3️⃣ join binding tails evenly with ease. 
.
👉🏻Swipe for a sneak peek and click the link in my bio to view the full post + where to get one! 🔗
.
If you struggle with binding your quilts as much as I do, I know I’m not alone when I say that the little ¼” notch in this ruler is worth its weight in gold. 🤯
.

Anyone else hate unfinished projects? 🙋🏼‍♀️ 
.
If I say I’m going to do something, I have to do it. And I won’t be able to stop thinking about it until it’s done. 
.
Enter these projects and commitments that I began (or talked about beginning) here on Instagram, but never actually 1) started or 2) finished. 🤦🏼‍♀️
.
Y’all are so good at holding me to my word. I get DMs on the regular asking me what happened to these orphaned projects and when I plan to bring them over the finish line. So LET'S DO THIS. 💪🏻
.
In no particular order, here's my to do list:
.
1️⃣Quilted Oven Gloves – I started making these oven gloves by @the.weekendquilter using Liberty of London fabric from an upcycled shirt. I finished one, but the second remains in my WIP pile.
.
2️⃣Quilted Sweatshirt – I was SO excited to start this project and then just simply didn’t have the time to finish it.
.
3️⃣Scrappy Blazing Arrow Quilt – I cut ALL the scraps for this quilt, put them in a bin, and then set them aside with the goal of making it one day.
.
4️⃣Scrappy Summer Tutorial – When I asked y’all if you wanted to know how I edited this Scrappy Summer pattern to look like this, 97% of you said yes, but then I never actually did it. Oops.
.
5️⃣Throw Pillow Patterns – I made these throw pillows for my living room last fall. When I asked y’all if you’d be interested in patterns, 95% of you said “Yes please!”, but I never got around to writing them.
.
6️⃣Quilted Apron Pattern – I made this cute garden apron out of upcycled men’s button-down shirts and 73% of you wanted to see how I did it. Coming soon!
.
7️⃣Upcycled Liberty of London Fabric – I bought 3 pieces of clothing made from @libertylondon fabric to use in projects, but I only deconstructed one. Can't wait to show y'all the other 2!
.
8️⃣Embroidery Flower Quilt – This idea is a REALLY OLD one. I came across this free pixelated flower pattern by @tilda_usa and wanted to attempt it using scraps from my stash. Then life happened and I never even started it.
.
9️⃣Donate More Quilts – I donated a handful of quilts to @wraptheworldwithquilts last year and I’ve been wanting to send a few more to free up space in my closets!

Remember when I bought a secondhand shirt made with Liberty of London fabric and deconstructed it for fabric? Well I'm at it again! ♻️🙌🏻
.
This time with this 100% cotton, J Crew button-down shirt made in the Ciara print of Liberty of London fabric. 😍
.
Thanks to their famed name, @libertylondon partners with other industries (like the clothing industry - hello J Crew!) to bring their signature floral designs to life. Often times, those items end up on secondhand clothing sites like @thredup at a really affordable price! 🤑
.
I bought this shirt on ThredUp for $20 with the hopes that I could get a yard of fabric out of it and save a little cash 👉🏻 Liberty of London fabric typically retails around $40/yard. 🫢
. 
Is it the same tana lawn weight fabric that you'd buy from a Liberty retailer like @duckadilly? Yep - identical! I bought a fat quarter of this same fabric from them just to confirm! 👍🏻
.
Excited to take my seam ripper to this one and report back! 🙃
.

This Liberty of London shirt from J Crew is officially quilting fabric! 🙌🏻
.
When I deconstruct button down shirts for fabric I use a combination of fabric scissors and my trusty seam ripper. 👍🏻 
.
I use the scissors to remove the buttons and collar, and then cut out all the seams so I’m left with the sleeves, two front panels and a back panel.
.
I then use my seam ripper to remove any tags and darts 👉🏻often times fabric is folded and stitched together for darts to give garments structure, so by ripping the stitches, you can end up with more fabric! 👏🏻
.

I deconstructed this secondhand Liberty of London shirt for fabric (the print is called Ciara!) with the hope of obtaining 1 yard…🤞🏻
.
❓How much fabric did I get?❓
.
Well, I came up a little short. All of the pieces below totaled about 3/4 yard. 💁🏼‍♀️
.
5 pieces cut from my button-down shirt:
▪️14" x 3"
▪️14" x 3"
▪️20" x 17"
▪️20" x 11"
▪️16" x 7.5"
.
Plus a few miscellaneous smaller pieces. 
.
👉🏻SO DID I SAVE $$? Was it worth it? Is this a worthwhile hack?! ✨ 
.
Yes and no depending one what you’re looking for. 👇🏻
.
1️⃣ This particular style of shirt yielded less fabric than the last Liberty of London blouse I cut apart (which only cost me $15). So next time I would either 1) buy a larger size, 2) pick a style that’s a bit more billowy, or 3) aim to pay less for it. 
.
2️⃣ Instead of paying $30 for .75 yard for new Liberty of London fabric, I paid $20 for this shirt and, while I got .75 yards of fabric, it’s not one continuous length (it’s 5 separate pieces). 
.
☝🏻MY TAKE: I personally find a lot of satisfaction in upcycling old fabric. Giving something a second life instead of buying new brings me joy. So while I only saved $10 this time around, these 5 scraps were saved from the trash and are going to get out to good use! ♻️🙌🏻
.

I’m making some EPP hexies with my upcycled Liberty of London fabric! 🙌🏻
.
AND I’m really NEW to this! So leave all your EPP tips in the comments below. 👇🏻 Am I using too much glue?! 🙃
.
I’ve experimented with English Paper Piecing (EPP) a little bit in the past, but I’ve never made hexies. 
.
I stick my 1.5” cardboard template to the wrong side of my fabric. Cut around the template leaving 1/4”-ish of fabric all the way around. Draw a glue line, fold, and rotate!
.
Link to the hexie templates and glue pen are in my bio!
.

Hi friends! 👋🏻 There are a LOT of new faces around here lately so it feels like it’s time for an updated intro! 👇🏻
.
My name is Amari (pronounced Am-Marie) and I started quilting in 2020. 🧵 It’s hard to believe that Next Gen Quilting’s 3rd birthday is right around the corner! 🤯
.
I live in San Francisco 🌉 with my husband and 7 month-old daughter, but am originally from the Midwest (born and raised in Nebraska 🌽 and spent over a decade in Chicago 💙).
.
No one in my family quilts or sews - I learned EVERYTHING I know from the internet. 💻 
.
I ❤️ love ❤️ sharing sustainable and budget-friendly quilting ideas. From upcycled clothing ♻️ for fabric and frankenbatting, to scrappy quilts and money-saving hacks 💵 - you’ll find it ALL here! ❗️Anyone remember when I used to share my monthly quilting budget reports and everything I bought to hold myself accountable? 🙃 Should I bring those back?! ⁉️
.
✨ My passion for collaborations with other quilters and partnerships with brands that I love runs DEEP 💕 - so if you have an idea, reach out! 📧
. 
Quilting is NOT my full-time job. I work a 9 to 5 and commute every day! 🚗 
.
If you’re new around here, WELCOME! 🫶🏻 Drop me a hello or a question in the comments below! And if you’ve been here since the beginning, THANK YOU for being here. 😘What else do you want to know? 🤪
.
Thanks for following along with my sustainable sewing journey - I love having y’all here! 🫶🏻
.

I'm traveling this weekend and am taking this Liberty of London EPP project with me on the airplane! ✈️ 
.
Did you know that you can take sewing scissors through airport security? ⁉️ Yep! ✂️ 
.
But they need to be small - less than 4 inches from the pivot point (👉🏻swipe to see) - and packed safely to avoid injury.
. 
I packed a small zip pouch with my scissors, a couple needles, thread, hexie templates, a glue pen, and fabric scraps...
.
And made it through airport security without issue! 🙌🏻
.

This was the VERY FIRST time I've taken a sewing project on a trip with me. ✈️ 
.
Here's how it went!👇🏻
.
I took a quick trip from San Francisco to Chicago this weekend for a family event. And I had a descent amount of time to kill on the 4.5 hour-long flights to and from Chicago. SO, I brought my English paper piecing (EPP) sewing project with me! 🧵 
.
See my previous post about what you need to know about getting sewing scissors through airport security. ✂️ 
.
What was I able to accomplish while on the airplane? I glue basted 100 hexies AND assembled 3 hexie flowers. 👉🏻Swipe to see!
.
Would I do it again? YES! 🙌🏻
.
Was it a little awkward taking out a glue stick and sewing needle while the passengers next to you wonder what the heck you're doing? FOR SURE. 🤭 But you'll get over it. 
.
And the best part? The flight time FLEW by while I worked on this project. Not to mention, the few good movies I took in along the way. 👏🏻
.
👉🏻Swipe through to see how many of you always, sometimes, or hope to someday travel with a sewing project!
.

I'm making slow, but steady progress on my Liberty of London English paper piecing (EPP) hexies - I'm up to 14 flowers! 💪🏻 🌸
.
BUT, while most of my glue-based hexies remain in tact as I bend them to stitch them together, every once and awhile, one of my papers FALLS OUT like this! 🙉
.

Sharing how I make my EPP hexie flowers! 
.
Each is made with seven 1-inch hexagons sewn together. Link to the templates I use are in my bio! 👆🏻
. 
There are many different ways to make these, but here’s what I do! 👇🏻
.
1️⃣ I double my thread - I find this to be the easiest way to hang onto my needle and strengthen my stitches.
.
2️⃣ I secure my first and last stitches with a loop knot (is there an official term for this?!).
.
3️⃣ I use a whip stitch and sew front to back, right to left (I feel like I have the most control this way! 🤷🏼‍♀️). 
.

Y'all know I love my FRANKENBATTING! 💛
.
And I've made two pieces for my next project! 👉🏻Swipe to see.
.
If you're not familiar with frankenbatting, it's a simple, no waste, budget-friendly way to use up all your small batting scraps. ♻️ 💵 
.
👇🏻Here's how to make it👇🏻
.
Sew together two pieces of batting using a zigzag stitch. Don't overlap the pieces - you want them to be flush against each other. The zigzag stitch will grab each piece as you sew and hold them together. Continue adding pieces using this method (I made three rows of frankenbatting and then sewed those rows together) until you have a piece large enough for your needs! 👏🏻
.
If you have small batting scraps, DON'T THROW THEM OUT! 🛑🗑️ Make frankenbatting. It'll be hidden inside your quilt project, so no one will ever see it! 🙃
.

Hey fabulous citizens of the quiltiverse! 
.
Let's take a quick minute to chat about the exciting and oh-so-important topic of fair compensation. Because we all want to feel like we're riding high on the waves of creativity, right?
.
Don't get me wrong, brand partnerships can be a blast, but let's remember, it takes two to tango folks! We're not asking for a shower of gold coins (though that would be nice!), just a little fairness in the mix.
.
Now, brace yourselves for the latest influencer program brought to you by Riley Blake Designs. Drumroll please - they're offering you the incredible perks of free fabric and a sweet $100 per month! Woohoo! 🎉
.
But before we break out the confetti, let's do a quick reality check: creating “a minimum” of two sewing projects for RBD's blog involves a whirlwind of time and effort - pattern development, sewing, photography, and tutorial writing. 
.
Is that even close to minimum wage or are we magicians making fabric art?
.
Oh, and let's not forget the cherry on top of the sewing machine - brand exclusivity! Who needs the freedom to collaborate with multiple fabric brands when you can have only one? Yay!
.
But hey, don't worry, we've got our creative spirit to keep us going! Freebies and questionable exposure might be fun, but they won't pay the bills or keep our sewing machines humming, will they?
.
So, here's a gentle nudge to all the amazing brands out there - we adore you, really! Let's turn this partnership dance into a fair and groovy one, where creativity meets appreciation and compensation. 💃💰
.
Keep your needles sharp and your time valued out there! 
.

If you haven't heard about all the incredible work that Gina Halladay & Beth Hawkins at @wraptheworldwithquilts are doing, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN?!
.
What started as a small non-profit to send quilts to Ukrainian refugees has EXPLODED into an enormous effort to support individuals impacted by disaster across the globe (including victims of the the earthquakes in Turkey & Syria and the recent wildfires in Maui). 
.
Remember when I donated 6 of my quilts to them last year? (👉🏻Swipe for a reminder!) Well at the time, they had received around 6,000 donated quilts. Today, they're up to a whopping 33,000 and counting! 🎉
.
Here are the 4 quilts I'm sending in support of their Maui relief efforts: my Cabin Peaks quilt (pattern by @cottonandjoy), Bear Cabin quilt (pattern by @porcupinesews_threads), Mae quilt (pattern by @wren.collective), and the very first quilt I ever made - which I called the Crater Lake Sunset quilt (rail fence pattern by @suzyquilts). 👉🏻Swipe to see!
.
DO YOU HAVE QUILTS TO GIVE? Here's how to get involved!👇🏻
.
Visit hellocottons.com. Gather up your quilts (new or barely used), give them a good wash and wrap them in a plastic bag, include a message with each (I printed out some pictures that show how each quilt was made), register the quilts on the website (so that you and the recipient can be connected via a QR code), box 'em up and ship them to Wrap Ukraine with Quilts c/o Hello Cottons, 1881 W. Traverse Parkway, Suite E-419, Lehi, UT 84043.
.
NO QUILTS, BUT STILL WANT TO HELP? 👉🏻Swipe to see a list of supplies that are in high demand among victims of the Maui wildfires. Gina and her team are collecting donations and sending them to the island. Box up new items you have at home or hop on Amazon & mail items directly to the Wrap the World with Quilts team! 🫶🏻
.
SHIPPING IS CHEAP. There is an inexpensive shipping label available on their website if needed. The $20 label allows you to ship up to 50 lbs of quilts and supplies!
.

.
Okay, so here's the scoop. I've got this snazzy Kayoko print Liberty of London fabric from my thrifted shorts, right? But guess what? Some of the fabric has interfacing fused to the backside. 🤨 
.
Here are my burning questions for you lovely folk:
.
1️⃣ Can I still use this stuff in a quilting project?
.
2️⃣ Will it get clingy and sticky when I hit it with the iron, causing fabric chaos?
.
3️⃣ Is it gonna play nice in the sandbox with other cotton fabrics that are free from interfacing, are are we talking wonky-shrinkage territory?
.
Before I dive headfirst into my next project, spill the beans! What are the must-know deets when dealing with these fabric pieces? 👇 
.
OR am I sweating for nothing? 😅 
.

Guess who's finally checking off those lingering to-dos from June? 📅 Yep, yours truly! 🙋🏼‍♀️
.
So, back then, I spilled the beans about my "Fabulous Nine" list, which, let's be real, was a tad ambitious for my own good. 😆 
.
It was a list of those projects and commitments I chatted about right here on Instagram but never quite made it to the 1) start or 2) finish line. 😬
.
But hold onto your creative hats, 'cause I've got news to share! I can officially kiss ✌️ items goodbye from that list!
.
First up, I promised more quilts for Wrap the World with Quilts, and if you missed it, scroll backs a few posts to hear about the 4 quilts I sent to help those affected by the Maui wildfires. 🌍🧵
.
Second - I finally finished these oven gloves! 🧤 Pattern is by @the.weekendquilter 
.
Or are they called pot holders? Oven mitts? Hot pads? Whatever you call these culinary heroes, mind are officially FINISHED!
.
These quilted oven gloves are - yep, you guessed it - crafted from the remnants of that upcycled Liberty of London shirt (swipe for a quick reminder!). Believe it or not, I had just ONE teeny step left - sewing the binding on the second glove - before I tossed these into my "Work in Progress" pile, never to be seen again. 🧤
.
And here's the real kicker – it only took me a grand total of 5 minutes to wrap these babies up. So, the real question is, what's the deal with my procrastination?! 🤔
.
Anyways, a few of you out there were wondering about the heat resistance of these kitchen gems. Truth be told, I didn't give that a ton of thought before whipping them up...
.
Mine have a single layer of cotton batting, which, let's face it, is about as heat-resistant as a kitchen towel for those sizzling pans. 😅 So next time, I'd probably double up on the batting or pair a layer of batting with some heat-resistant fabric like Insul-Brite. 🔥🧵
.

If you follow along on stories, you know that a couple weeks ago I committed to the Coda Quilted Coat SAL hosted by @alderwoodstudio. 🤪
.
I went all in! Bought the pattern, got it printed at mega scale at FedEx, and even stocked up on interfacing to trace those pattern pieces and whip up a prototype of this coat-to-be. 📄✂️ 
.
And then, like a plot twist in a good book, life decided to do its thing, and whoosh, suddenly I was three weeks behind schedule! 😂
.
But hey, here's the scoop: Officially, we're in week 3 (almost 4) of this sew-along adventure, but I'm strutting in fashionably late to share my week 1 wins. Better late than never, right? 💁🏼‍♀️
.
Here's the rundown of my week 1 accomplishments:
.
1️⃣ Decided on my coat size. According to the measurements, I was right smack in between Small and Medium, so I'm going with a little bit of both and splitting the difference – the best of both worlds, baby! 🌟
.
2️⃣ Cut out those pattern pieces. But to keep my mega-printed pattern in tip-top shape, I got creative with some interfacing magic (Pellon 830), traced it, and snipped away. 💃
.
3️⃣ Made a toile. Ah, the "toile" – also known as a "twahl." I had to Google that one! It's a fancy word for a simple prototype that helps you fine-tune the fit and make any necessary size adjustments.
.
So, there you have it! While the rest of the Coda Quilt Sew Along community is zooming ahead into week 4, I'm just now catching up on week 2's instructions. Life happens, but the sewing party must go on! 🎉👗
.

QUILTING TIP: Next time you have a quilt pattern with templates (like these hexies), don’t trace them and cut them out individually - do THIS instead!👇🏻
.
Measure the widest part of your template and cut fabric strips of that size. 
.
Make sub cuts the length of your template and then trace the remaining lines. 
.
Skip the scissors and trim multiple pieces at once with a ruler and rotary cutter for straight, accurate cuts! 👍🏻
.

Hello Y seams! 🤪 This is my first time ever attempting these so…🤦🏼‍♀️
.
I’m sewing together a bunch of hexies using Y seams to avoid having to do EPP. 😆 …But I’m not very good at it yet and most of my rows look like the second image here! 🙈
.
Seams are not flat and threads are everywhere as I stitch and re-stitch each seam trying to get them right! 🤯
.
The hardest part is that you need to start and stop sewing 1/4” from each edge. And even though I have it all marked, the struggle is real. 😂 
.
It seems as though you need to have all of your hexies the EXACT same size and line each piece up JUST right to get this to work. 
.
Any tips? Drop them in the comments below! 👇🏻👇🏻👇🏻
.
#hexies #quiltingismytherapy #quiltville #quiltersofinstagram #quiltsofinstagram #igquiltcommunity #quilter #yseams #epp #sewingtricks #quiltingtricks #sewingtips #quiltingtips #sewinghacks #quiltinghacks #beginnersewing

QUILTING TIP: This step is a GAME CHANGER when sewing hexies together using Y seams.👇🏻
.
One of the HARDEST parts about sewing Y seams is that you need to start and stop sewing exactly 1/4” from the edge of each piece. Here’s how to get it right EVERY TIME.👇🏻
.
Using a water soluble pen (and on the wrong side of the fabric), make a little X in each corner 1/4” in from the edge.
.
THAT’S IT. Take the time to mark all your hexies - you’ll thank me later! 😘
.
#hexies #quiltingismytherapy #quiltersofinstagram #quiltsofinstagram #quilter #yseams #sewinghacks #quiltingtips #sewingtips #sewingtricks #quiltingtricks #quiltville #fabricpens

Skip hand sewing EPP and sew hexies with your MACHINE! 🤯
.
Did you know you can make a hexie project with Y seams? It’s SO MUCH faster than traditional English Paper Piecing! 👏🏻
.
Cut out your templates, mark 1/4” from each edge, and sew two rows of hexies. This next step is IMPORTANT!👇🏻
.
Place the two rows right sides together and sew one seam at a time to connect them. DON’T sew all the way to the edge (leave 1/4” space on either side) and DO turn each hexie to line up with the next as you sew (it takes a little finagling!). 
.

I’m making a pixel quilt with 1” fabric scraps!
.
I’m using the Embroidery Flower quilt pattern by @tilda_usa and EasyPiecing Grid panels from @tensisters_handicraft 🤗
.
#tildafabric #pixelquilt #embroideryflowerquilt #scrappyquilt #igquiltingcommunity #quiltingismytherapy #quiltersofinstagram #fabricscraps #fabricscrapsproject #pixelatedquilt 
.

STEP 1
.
I’m using something called EasyPiecing Grid Panels by @tensisters_handicraft to make my pixelated quilt! Learn more 👇🏻
.
These panels are fusible interfacing with gridlines on them. I’m using the 2” grid panels, which will give me 1.5” finished squares.
.
The panels are incredibly simple to use. 1️⃣ Lay the panel on your ironing board, textured side UP. The texture is a thin layer of adhesive that will eventually stick to your fabric squares. 
.
2️⃣ Arrange your fabric squares in the grid and 3️⃣ press with a hot iron to fuse them to the interfacing.
.
Don’t worry if your pieces don’t go all the way to the end of the gridlines. The grid is designed to be slightly larger than your pieces so that there is room to fold and sew your rows and columns together. 🤯
.
Will show y’all how to do that next! 🤗
.
#quiltingismytherapy #quiltersofinstagram #quiltsofinstagram #easypiecinggrid #tensisterseasypiecinggrid #scrappyquilt #embroideryflowerquilt #instaquilts #sewinginterfacing

LOVING this fusible grid interfacing for my pixel quilt! 🤩🤍
.
You simply iron your squares onto the interfacing, and then sew the columns and rows together - VIOLA! 🪄 
.
👉🏻Swipe to see how all the seams nest beautifully together on the backside! 👏🏻
.
I sewed all my rows together, pressed all the seams in the same direction, clipped them (I’ll show you how to do this in my next video!), and then sewed all the columns. SO FAST & EASY! 💕 🧵

STEP 2 - are you ready for it?! 🤗
.
I’m using the @tensisters_handicraft EasyPiecing Grid Panels to make the @tilda_usa Embroidery Flower pixel quilt.
.
Step 1 was to simply iron your fabric squares onto the grid panels. Easy peasy. 👍🏻
.
Step 2 is where sh** gets real because it’s time to sew! 😆
.
Fold rows 1 and 2 right sides together. Sew them together using a 1/4” seam. Repeat until all of your rows are connected and your panels look like little accordions! 🪗😂
.
❗️These interfacing grid panels STAY IN YOUR QUILT. I got a few questions about this - no I won’t be removing them!❗️🤍
.
#quiltingismytherapy #quiltersofinstagram #easypiecinggrid #easypiecing #tensisterseasypiecinggrid #scrappyquilt #embroideryflowerquilt #tildafabric #sewinginterfacing #quiltinghacks #sewinghacks

STEP 3 - clip the seams! ✂️
.
After you’ve sewn all your rows, snip the seams vertically (DO NOT cut through your stitches - if you accidentally do though, don’t sweat it 😅 the interfacing will hold your quilt together!). 💪🏻
.
Why are we doing this? This is going to allow for the seams to nest once we sew the columns together. 👍🏻
.
In case you missed it, here’s what’s going on around here: I’m trying the @tensisters_handicraft EasyPiecing Grid to make a pixel quilt (the Embroidery Flower quilt by @tilda_usa). 🎉 
.

STEP 4: Press the seams of each row is OPPOSITE directions. ↔️
.
All the clipping I did in step 3 is finally paying off! 👏🏻Pressing in opposite directions will allow for my seams to nest beautifully once I sew the columns together. 🙏
.
